'''KatÃ´ Shidzue''' ([[1897]] - [[2001]]) was a 20th Century [[Japan| Japanese]] [[feminist]] and one of the first women elected to the [[Japanese Diet]]. KatÃ´ was best known as a pioneer in the birth control movement and a strong supporter of labour reform.
+
'''KatÃ´ Shidzue''' ([[1897]] - [[2001]]) was a 20th Century [[Japan| Japanese]] [[feminist]] and one of the first women elected to the [[Diet of Japan]]. KatÃ´ was best known as a pioneer in the birth control movement and a strong supporter of labour reform.
==Bio==
==Bio==
â
KatÃ´ Shidzue was born on [[March 2]] [[1897]] to an elite family and was married to the progressive [[Baron Ishimoto Keikichi]] at age 17. Shortly after their marriage, Shidzue and her husband moved to the [[Miike]] coalfield in [[Kyushu]]. For three years, the witnessed the horrendous conditions under which the men and women there worked. In [[1919]], the couple moved to the [[United States]], where Shidzue studied in a secretarial program in New York. After the couple returned to Japan, the Baron began working for the expanding Japanese empire, and the couple grew apart. She became involved with labor organizer [[KatÃ´ Kanju]] (who was also married). Only after many years was she given permission by the Imperial Household Agency to end her marriage to the Baron and to marry KatÃ´ Kanju. In [[1946]] KatÃ´ Shidzue joined the [[Japan Socialist Party]], and was elected to the [[Japanese Diet]]. She continued her involvement in Japanese politics even after leaving the Diet, and died on [[December 22]] [[2001]]
+
KatÃ´ Shidzue was born on [[March 2]] [[1897]] to an elite family and was married to the progressive [[Baron Ishimoto Keikichi]] at age 17. Shortly after their marriage, Shidzue and her husband moved to the [[Miike]] coalfield in [[Kyushu]]. For three years, the witnessed the horrendous conditions under which the men and women there worked. In [[1919]], the couple moved to the [[United States]], where Shidzue studied in a secretarial program in New York. After the couple returned to Japan, the Baron began working for the expanding Japanese empire, and the couple grew apart. She became involved with labor organizer [[KatÃ´ Kanju]] (who was also married). Only after many years was she given permission by the Imperial Household Agency to end her marriage to the Baron and to marry KatÃ´ Kanju. In [[1946]] KatÃ´ Shidzue joined the [[Japan Socialist Party]], and was elected to the [[Diet of Japan]]. She continued her involvement in Japanese politics even after leaving the Diet, and died on [[December 22]] [[2001]]
==Political Notes==
==Political Notes==
* '''[[1922]]''' - Acted as a guide to American feminist [[Margaret Sanger]], whom she had met while in New York in [[1920]]. Shidzue provided important support, first helping her gain permission to land in Japan, and then to speak in public on birth control. In the following years, Shidzue brought Sanger to Japan six more times.
* '''[[1922]]''' - Acted as a guide to American feminist [[Margaret Sanger]], whom she had met while in New York in [[1920]]. Shidzue provided important support, first helping her gain permission to land in Japan, and then to speak in public on birth control. In the following years, Shidzue brought Sanger to Japan six more times.
* '''[[1937]]''' - Arrested because of her opposition to the militarist government's policy of producing as many children as possible.
* '''[[1937]]''' - Arrested because of her opposition to the militarist government's policy of producing as many children as possible.
â
* '''[[1946]] - [[1974]]''' - Served in the [[Japanese Diet]].
+
* '''[[1946]] - [[1974]]''' - Served in the [[Diet of Japan]].
* '''[[1948]]''' - Co-founded the [[Japan Family Planning Association]]
* '''[[1948]]''' - Co-founded the [[Japan Family Planning Association]]
* '''[[1988]]''' - Received the [[United Nations]] Population Award.
* '''[[1988]]''' - Received the [[United Nations]] Population Award.
